title: Error being constantly printed
body:
#### Current Behavior

Consider a project folder that complies with [the `is_js_project` check](https://github.com/starship/starship/blob/f267b3debe66da6d94ba3e4a329eb524f81e946c/src/modules/nodejs.rs#L13-L18):

```rust
    let is_js_project = context
        .try_begin_scan()?
        .set_files(&["package.json"])
        .set_extensions(&["js"])
        .set_folders(&["node_modules"])
        .is_match();
```

Also consider that the user does not have `node` installed (perhaps because the project contains 2 or more languages and the user works on only one of them, which is my case).

In this case `starship` will print the following line on every rendering of the shell prompt while the user remains in said project:
>  ERROR starship::utils > Executing command "node" failed by: Os { code: 2, kind: NotFound, message: "No such file or directory" }

I assume the same scenario plays out with other missing executables too.

#### Expected Behavior/Possible Solution

I am not sure what would be the best way to deal with such a scenario. I have a handfull options in mind:
1. **Silence the error**. Assuming #982 was merged intentionally and we don't want to simply revert it, this may have to be controlled by a config option.
2. **Reflect the error in the prompt itself**. For example, printing `missing!` in place of the version number may be enough to clue the user in.
3. **Print it once and then silence it**. This way we can still be expressive to the user and not spam them.
4. **Introduce `starship doctor` to print these errors**. `doctor` is starting to become a staple of command line tools lately and I have found it very useful. This option would be similar to 1 where `starship prompt` will silence the errors and `starship doctor` prints them.
5. **Print errors in `starship explain`**. The same as 4 but added to `explain` instead of a new subcommand.

In all cases, I would expect the error message to read more like English prose, eg:
> ERROR Failed to find "node" executable. Maybe it isn't installed?

I feel confident to tackle this in a PR once I have some direction on how others are more comfortable for this to be tackled.

#### Environment
- Starship version: 0.38.0
- fish version: fish, version 3.1.0
- Operating system: Mac OS 10.14.6
- Terminal emulator: Alacritty <unknown version>

#### Relevant Shell Configuration

```bash
eval (starship init fish)

[ -f /usr/local/share/autojump/autojump.fish ]; and source /usr/local/share/autojump/autojump.fish

source /usr/local/share/chruby/chruby.fish
source /usr/local/share/chruby/auto.fish
```
